query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Ma qui la morta poesì resurga, 8 o sante Muse, poi che vostro sono; 9 e qui Calïopè alquanto surga,
10 seguitando il mio canto con quel suono 11 di cui le Piche misere sentiro 12 lo colpo tal, che disperar perdono.
query.result:
**English:**
7 But here may dead poetry rise again, 8 O holy Muses, since I am yours; 9 and here may Calliope rise somewhat,
10 following my song with that sound 11 from which the wretched Magpies felt 12 such a blow that they despaired of pardon.
**Old English:**
7 Ac her ða deadan leoðu eftal arise, 8 e ða halgan mægðu, siððan ic eowerra wæs; 9 and her ða Calliope sum deal arise,
10 folgiende minum sange mid ðam swæge 11 ðe ða earman Picas ða ðone dynt gehyrdon 12 ðæt hi forhtedon ðæt hi næfre miltse ne geearnodon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Dolce color d’orïental zaffiro, 14 che s’accoglieva nel sereno aspetto 15 del mezzo, puro infino al primo giro,
16 a li occhi miei ricominciò diletto, 17 tosto ch’io usci’ fuor de l’aura morta 18 che m’avea contristati li occhi e ’l petto.
query.result:
**English:**
13 Sweet color of oriental sapphire, 14 which was gathered in the serene aspect 15 of the middle, pure up to the first circle,
16 began to delight my eyes again, 17 as soon as I emerged from the dead air 18 that had saddened my eyes and my chest.
**Old English:**
13 Swete heow of easterne saffir, 14 ðe ðær onfeng on ðam fægre gesihðe 15 ðæs middes, clæne oð ðone forman hring,
16 ongunnon ða ða mine eagan ða gelician, 17 sona swa ic of ðam deadan lyfte gewat 18 ðe me ða eagan and ða breost awearg.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Lo bel pianeto che d’amar conforta 20 faceva tutto rider l’orïente, 21 velando i Pesci ch’erano in sua scorta.
query.result:
**English:**
19 The beautiful planet that comforts with love 20 was making all the east laugh, 21 veiling the Pisces that were in its escort.
**Old English:**
19 Se fægere steorra ðe ðurh lufe geblissath 20 worhte eall ðone eastan to hlihhanne, 21 bewrigen ða Fiscas ðe wæron on his geferrædene.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 I’ mi volsi a man destra, e puosi mente 23 a l’altro polo, e vidi quattro stelle 24 non viste mai fuor ch’a la prima gente.
query.result:
**English:**
22 I turned to the right, and fixed my attention 23 on the other pole, and saw four stars 24 never seen before except by the first people.
**Old English:**
22 Ic me wende on ða swiðran hand, and geseah 23 ðone oðerne steorran, and geseah feower steorran 24 ðe næfre ær ne geseah buton ða forman men.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Goder pareva ’l ciel di lor fiammelle: 26 oh settentrïonal vedovo sito, 27 poi che privato se’ di mirar quelle!
28 Com’ io da loro sguardo fui partito, 29 un poco me volgendo a l ’altro polo, 30 là onde ’l Carro già era sparito,
31 vidi presso di me un veglio solo, 32 degno di tanta reverenza in vista, 33 che più non dee a padre alcun figliuolo.
query.result:
**English:**
25 The sky seemed to rejoice with their flames: 26 oh widowed northern region, 27 since you are deprived of gazing upon them!
28 When I had departed from their sight, 29 turning a little toward the other pole, 30 where the Wain had already disappeared,
31 I saw near me an old man alone, 32 worthy of so much reverence in appearance, 33 that no son owes more to a father.
**Old English:**
25 Blissigende wæs ðæs heofones rodor ðurh heora fyrbecu, 26 ea, norðeweard wuduwe stede, 27 syððan ðu eart bescyred ðara gesyhða!
28 Swa ic ða fram heora gesyhðum gewende, 29 lythwon me wendan to ðam oðrum steorran, 30 ðær ðæs wanan wænes wæs ær forð;
31 ða geseah ic ænne ealdne wer standan 32 wyrðlicne on wlite, swa me ðuhte, 33 ðæt nænig meara næfre mare ne geseah.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Lunga la barba e di pel bianco mista 35 portava, a’ suoi capelli simigliante, 36 de’ quai cadeva al petto doppia lista.
query.result:
**English:**
34 His beard was long and mixed with white hair, 35 similar to his hair, 36 of which a double strand fell on his chest.
**Old English:**
34 Lang was his beard and of white hair y-mixt, 35 With eyen stepe and browes black y-bent, 36 Of his heed and of his shuldres it y-went.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Li raggi de le quattro luci sante 38 fregiavan sì la sua faccia di lume, 39 ch’i’ ’l vedea come ’l sol fosse davante.
query.result:
**English:**
37 The rays of the four holy lights 38 so adorned his face with light, 39 that I saw him as if the sun were before me.
**Old English:**
37 Þæs feower halgan leohtes leoman 38 freoðodon swa his ansyn mid leohte, 39 ðæt ic hine geseah swa ðone sunnan beforan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 «Chi siete voi che contro al cieco fiume 41 fuggita avete la pregione etterna?», 42 diss’ el, movendo quelle oneste piume.
query.result:
**English:**
40 "Who are you who against the blind river 41 have fled from eternal prison?", 42 he said, moving those honorable feathers.
**Old English:**
40 "Hwa sindon ge ðe ongean ðone blinde flod 41 flugon ða ecan carcerne?", 42 cwæð he, hrepode ða heanlican fiðru.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 «Chi v’ha guidati, o che vi fu lucerna, 44 uscendo fuor de la profonda notte 45 che sempre nera fa la valle inferna?
46 Son le leggi d’abisso così rotte? 47 o è mutato in ciel novo consiglio, 48 che, dannati, venite a le mie grotte?».
query.result:
**English:**
43 "Who guided you, or who was your lantern, 44 emerging from the deep night 45 that always makes the infernal valley black?
46 Are the laws of the abyss so broken? 47 Or has a new counsel changed in heaven, 48 that you, damned souls, come to my caves?"
**Old English:**
43 "Hwa eow lædde, oððe hwæt wæs eow leoht, 44 ða ge út eodon of ðære deopan niht, 45 ðe symle wonn wyrceð hellegrund?
46 Sindon ða geset ðæs grundes swa toworpene? 47 oððe is on heofonum niwe ræd geðoht, 48 ðæt ge, forwyrde, cumað to minum scræfum?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Lo duca mio allor mi diè di piglio, 50 e con parole e con mani e con cenni 51 reverenti mi fé le gambe e ’l ciglio.
query.result:
**English:**
49 My leader then took hold of me, 50 and with words and with hands and with gestures 51 respectful he made my legs and my brow [bow].
**Old English:**
49 Þa me min latteow ðær onfeng, 50 and me mid wordum and mid handum and mid hleorum 51 arfæstne geteahte ða sceoncan and ða neb.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Poscia rispuose lui: «Da me non venni: 53 donna scese del ciel, per li cui prieghi 54 de la mia compagnia costui sovvenni.
query.result:
**English:**
52 Then he replied to him: "I did not come of my own accord: 53 a lady descended from heaven, at whose entreaties 54 I rescued this man from my company.
**Old English:**
52 Þa him andswarode and cwæð: "Ne com ic hider selfa: 53 wīf āstāh of heofonum, ðurh ðære bene 54 ic ðisne of ðinum gefērscipe āhredde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 Ma da ch’è tuo voler che più si spieghi 56 di nostra condizion com’ ell’ è vera, 57 esser non puote il mio che a te si nieghi.
query.result:
**English:**
55 But since it is your wish that I explain more fully 56 about our true condition, 57 my will cannot deny you.
**Old English:**
55 Ac siððan hit is ðin willa ðæt ðu mare wille 56 ongitan umbe ure gecynd hu he bið, 57 ne mæg min willa nates ðe wiðsacan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Questi non vide mai l’ultima sera; 59 ma per la sua follia le fu sì presso, 60 che molto poco tempo a volger era.
query.result:
**English:**
58 This one never saw the final evening; 59 but because of his madness he came so close to it, 60 that there was very little time left to turn back.
**Old English:**
58 Þes ne geseah næfre ða æftemestan dæg; 59 ac for his dysigle him wæs ðæs lifes wyn 60 swiðe near oððe ða gena.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Sì com’ io dissi, fui mandato ad esso 62 per lui campare; e non lì era altra via 63 che questa per la quale i’ mi son messo.
query.result:
**English:**
61 As I have said, I was sent to him 62 to save him; and there was no other way 63 than this on which I have set out.
**Old English:**
61 Swa ic ðe secge, ic wæs asend ðider 62 ðurh hine to hreddenne; ne wæs ðær oder weg 63 buton ðeos ylce ðe ic on wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Mostrata ho lui tutta la gente ria; 65 e ora intendo mostrar quelli spirti 66 che purgan sé sotto la tua balìa.
query.result:
**English:**
64 I have shown him all the wicked people; 65 and now I intend to show him those spirits 66 who are purging themselves under your authority.
**Old English:**
64 Ic hæbbe him ealle ða yflan men aýawed; 65 and nu ic pence ða gastas ateónan 66 ðe him clænsiað under ðinum anwealde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Com’ io l’ho tratto, saria lungo a dirti; 68 de l’alto scende virtù che m’aiuta 69 conducerlo a vederti e a udirti.
query.result:
**English:**
67 How I led him here would be long to tell; 68 from above descends a power that aids me 69 to lead him to see you and to hear you.
**Old English:**
67 Hu ic hine ðær fram brohte, ðæt wære lang to secganne; 68 of ðam hehstan stigeð miht ðe me fylst, 69 ðæt ic hine læde ðe to geseonne and ðin word to gehyranne.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Or ti piaccia gradir la sua venuta: 71 libertà va cercando, ch’è sì cara, 72 come sa chi per lei vita rifiuta.
query.result:
**English:**
70 Now may it please you to welcome his coming: 71 he goes seeking liberty, which is so dear, 72 as he knows who for her sake refuses life.
**Old English:**
70 Nu ðe gelimpðe ðæt ðu his cyme gecnawe: 71 freodom he secð, ðe is swiðe dyre, 72 swa he wât ðe hire for ðæt lif forlêt.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Tu ’l sai, ché non ti fu per lei amara 74 in Utica la morte, ove lasciasti 75 la vesta ch’al gran dì sarà sì chiara.
query.result:
**English:**
73 You know it, for death in Utica was not bitter to you, 74 where you left behind the garment that will be so bright on the great day.
**Old English:**
73 ðu hit wást, ðe ðe næfre ðuhte ðeáð bitre 74 on Utica, ðær ðu forléte 75 ðone háman ðe on ðam miclan dæge bið swíðe beorht.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Non son li editti etterni per noi guasti, 77 ché questi vive e Minòs me non lega; 78 ma son del cerchio ove son li occhi casti
79 di Marzia tua, che ’n vista ancor ti priega, 80 o santo petto, che per tua la tegni: 81 per lo suo amore adunque a noi ti piega.
query.result:
**English:**
76 The eternal edicts are not broken for us, 77 because this one lives and Minos does not bind me; 78 but I am from the circle where the chaste eyes are,
79 of your Marcia, who in her appearance still prays to you, 80 O holy breast, that you hold her as yours: 81 for her love, therefore, bend to us.
**Old English:**
76 Ne sind ða ecan ecan ðurh us toworpene, 77 forðæm ðeos leofað and Minos me ne bindeð; 78 ac ic eom of ðæm rince ðær ða clænan eagan sind,
79 ðinre Martian, ðe on gesyhðe ðe gyt biddeð, 80 ðu halige breost, ðæt ðu ðe hi to ðinre healde: 81 ðurh hire lufe ðonne to us gebig.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 Lasciane andar per li tuoi sette regni; 83 grazie riporterò di te a lei, 84 se d’esser mentovato là giù degni».
query.result:
**English:**
82 Let her go through your seven kingdoms; 83 I will report back to her about you, 84 if you are worthy of being mentioned down there.
**Old English:**
82 Læt hi ðurh ðine seofon rice; 83 ic ðe secge ðanc ðær ðu ðær bist, 84 gif ðu ðæs wyrðe bist ðæt ðu ðær gemyndig sie.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 «Marzïa piacque tanto a li occhi miei 86 mentre ch’i’ fu’ di là», diss’ elli allora, 87 «che quante grazie volse da me, fei.
query.result:
**English:**
85 "Marzia pleased my eyes so much 86 while I was there," he said then, 87 "that I granted her every favor she asked of me.
**Old English:**
85 "Marzia licode swa ðinum eagum 86 ða hwile ðe ic ðær wæs," cwæð he ða, 87 "ðæt ic hire ealle ða gife sealde ðe heo wolde."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Or che di là dal mal fiume dimora, 89 più muover non mi può, per quella legge 90 che fatta fu quando me n’usci’ fora.
query.result:
**English:**
88 Now that he dwells beyond the evil river, 89 he can move me no more, because of that law 90 that was made when I exited from there.
**Old English:**
88 Nu ðe he ofer ðone yflan flod wunað, 89 ne mæg he me leng tosceððan, ðurh ða lage 90 ðe geworht wæs ða ic ðanon gewat.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Ma se donna del ciel ti move e regge, 92 come tu di’, non c’è mestier lusinghe: 93 bastisi ben che per lei mi richegge.
query.result:
**English:**
91 But if a lady from heaven moves and guides you, 92 as you say, there is no need for flattery: 93 it is enough for you that I ask you for her sake.
**Old English:**
91 Ac gif ðu eart ðurh ðone heofonlican wif gewiððod and gerædd, 92 swa ðu secge, ðonne nis ðearf ðæt ðu ðe ðurh flaterunge bidde: 93 ðe mæg ðyncan genoh ðæt ðu ðurh hi ðæs bidde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Questa isoletta intorno ad imo ad imo, 101 là giù colà dove la batte l’onda, 102 porta di giunchi sovra ’l molle limo:
103 null’ altra pianta che facesse fronda 104 o indurasse, vi puote aver vita, 105 però ch’a le percosse non seconda.
query.result:
**English:**
100 This little island around its very base, 101 down there where the waves beat upon it, 102 bears reeds upon the soft mud:
103 no other plant that could put forth leaves 104 or grow hard could have life there, 105 because it does not withstand the beatings.
**Old English:**
100 Þeos lytla iegland ymbutan ðone niðemestan, 101 þær niðer þær ða yða slæð, 102 bærð ðær ryscas ofer ðam hnescan læge:
103 nan oðer wudu ðe leafum geweoxe 104 oððe heard wurde, ne mihte þær wunian, 105 forðæm ðe he ða dynu ne ðolode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Poscia non sia di qua vostra reddita; 107 lo sol vi mosterrà, che surge omai, 108 prendere il monte a più lieve salita».
query.result:
**English:**
106 Henceforth, let your return not be this way; 107 the sun, which is now rising, will show you 108 how to take the mountain by an easier ascent.
**Old English:**
106 Heonon nis eower sied wedergong; 107 sunu sunne ðe be suðan is 108 eow wile geswutelian ðone læssan weg.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Così sparì; e io sù mi levai 110 sanza parlare, e tutto mi ritrassi 111 al duca mio, e li occhi a lui drizzai.
query.result:
**English:**
109 Thus he disappeared; and I rose up 110 without speaking, and withdrew myself entirely 111 to my leader, and fixed my eyes on him.
**Old English:**
109 Swa he forð gewat; and ic upp aras 110 butan spræce, and eallunga me beloc 111 to ðam læde min, and ða eagan to him sette.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 El cominciò: «Figliuol, segui i miei passi: 113 volgianci in dietro, ché di qua dichina 114 questa pianura a’ suoi termini bassi».
query.result:
**English:**
112 He began: "Son, follow my steps: 113 let us turn back, for from here slopes down 114 this plain to its lowest depths."
**Old English:**
112 He ða ongan: "Sunu, folgað minum sporum: 113 uton wendan eft, forðan ðe ðeos denu 114 hleonað niðer to ðam nedestan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 L’alba vinceva l’ora mattutina 116 che fuggia innanzi, sì che di lontano 117 conobbi il tremolar de la marina.
query.result:
**English:**
115 Dawn was conquering the morning hour 116 that was fleeing before it, so that from afar 117 I recognized the trembling of the shoreline.
**Old English:**
115 Dægredsiges ða morgentid oferwann, 116 ðe ðær beforan fleah, ða ðæt feorran geseah 117 ofer lagufæsten leoman scinende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Noi andavam per lo solingo piano 119 com’ om che torna a la perduta strada, 120 che ’nfino ad essa li pare ire in vano.
query.result:
**English:**
118 We went on through the solitary plain 119 like someone who returns to the lost road, 120 who until he reaches it seems to go in vain.
**Old English:**
118 We eodon forð ðurh ðone weste wudu 119 swa swa se ðe cymeð to ðære forlorenan stræte, 120 ðe him ðinceð ðæt he hi ne mæge findan ær.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 Quando noi fummo là ’ve la rugiada 122 pugna col sole, per essere in parte 123 dove, ad orezza, poco si dirada,
124 ambo le mani in su l’erbetta sparte 125 soavemente ’l mio maestro pose: 126 ond’ io, che fui accorto di sua arte,
127 porsi ver’ lui le guance lagrimose; 128 ivi mi fece tutto discoverto 129 quel color che l’inferno mi nascose.
query.result:
**English:**
121 When we were there where the dew 122 fights with the sun, because it is in a place 123 where, in the breeze, it evaporates little,
124 both his hands he spread out on the grass 125 gently, and my master placed them: 126 whereupon I, who was aware of his art,
127 turned my tearful cheeks toward him; 128 there he made me fully reveal 129 that color which Hell had hidden from me.
**Old English:**
121 Þa we wæron þær ðær seo deaw 122 winnende wæs wið ðone sunnan, forðæm hit wæs on ðære stowe 123 þær, on ðære lyfte, lyt ðurh ðone wind tosceacen,
124 ba his handa on ðam grase awearp 125 softe, and min lareow ðær gesette: 126 þa ic, ðe wæs war his cræftes,
127 awende to him mine tearfulle wlite; 128 þær he me geworhte ealne æteowedne 129 ðone hiw ðe hel me ær forhydde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Venimmo poi in sul lito diserto, 131 che mai non vide navicar sue acque 132 omo, che di tornar sia poscia esperto.
query.result:
**English:**
130 We came then to the deserted shore, 131 which never saw a man sail its waters 132 who was later able to return.
**Old English:**
130 We comon ða to ðam wæstenne strande, 131 ðe næfre ær ne geseah seon sceolde 132 ofer ða wægas wudu bundenne, 133 ðæt he eft cuman scolde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 Quivi mi cinse sì com’ altrui piacque: 134 oh maraviglia! ché qual elli scelse 135 l’umile pianta, cotal si rinacque
136 subitamente là onde l’avelse.
query.result:
**English:**
133 There it encircled me as it pleased another: 134 oh marvel! for as he chose 135 the humble plant, so it was reborn
136 suddenly from where he had plucked it.
**Old English:**
133 Þær me ymbclypte swa swa oðrum licode: 134 ea, wundor! forðæm swa swa he geceas 135 ðone eadmodan telg, swa he eft gewearð
136 hraðe ðær he hine ær of ateah.
